35. Hull described the need for a publication which could be es¬
tablished as the central source of all educational broadcasting acti¬
vities, a top-flight vehicle possibly along TV Digest or Edgar Dale
land-grant newsletter lines. It was recognised tnefc such a newsletter

36. The Board discussed possible space in KETA for a national pub¬
licity office, the need for a national address and telephone, the need
to dramatise the movement for the public, the need for HAEB public re¬
lations and promotion, and HAEB obligation to assume this responsibility
of promotion for the entire movement. Bronson moved that the President
and officers of HAEB be instructed immediately to make an attempt to
secure funds for the establishment of a full-time public relations pro¬
gram designed to improve public understanding of educational broadcast¬
ing. Schenkkan seconded and approval was unanimous•
37. Discussed also were other possible measures of action* activa¬
tion of an HAEB Public Relations Committee to transmit regular materials
to a Hew fork area association member for processing to leading critics,
columnists end syndication people; the similarity of the public relations
problem and need on the part of the local station; the need eventually
to move HAEB Headquarters to Hew York; the fact that public relations
for the movement is in the long run dependent on the programming.
Schooloy pointed to the possibility of approaching several founda¬
tions for advice in meeting this critical public relations problem*
Vogl suggested that broadcast equipment manufacturers might be ap¬
proached by HAEB for donations to implement the public relations plan.
Such might b© mutually advantageous.

serve.
